item.title: Configuring RDP on XUbuntu
item.description: Install xrdp 1# Install all prerequisites 2sudo apt-get install xrdp xfce4 xfce4-goodies -y 3 4# Set the session manager to xfce 5echo xfce4-session > ~/.xsession Configure startwm.sh 1# Edit the startwm.sh file 2sudo nano /etc/xrdp/startwm.sh Comment these lines out: 1#test -x /etc/X11/Xsession && exec /etc/X11/Xsession 2#exec /bin/sh /etc/X11/Xsession add these lines: 1startxfce4 Configure the firewall 1sudo ufw allow 3389/tcp Ensure user is member of ssl-cert group 1sudo adduser xrdp ssl-cert Restart xrdp 1sudo systemctl enable xrdp 2sudo systemctl start xrdp If the session exits when you login Enable MultiUser mode Fix taken from https://github.

item.title: Piping Windows EventLog to OpInsight (or other tcp endpoint)
item.description: Quick and Dirty Pipes the last 10 events from the kube-proxy source to OpInsight (or other tcp endpoint) in json format using Powershell. 1Get-EventLog -Source 'kube-proxy' -LogName 'EKS' -Newest 10 | ForEach-Object { 2 $Endpoint = https://eu.webhook.logs.insight.rapid7.com/v1/noformat/<YourToken>" 3 4 $JsonBody = @{ 5 "idx" = $_.Index, 6 "src" = $_.Source 7 "inst" = $_.InstanceId 8 "time" = $_.Time, 9 "event" = $_.Message, 10 } | ConvertTo-Json 11 12 Invoke-RestMethod -Method Post -Uri $Endpoint -Body $JsonBody -ContentType "application/json" 13} You can of course use a function but this is something I only tend to have to use if EKS’ managed windows nodes are misbehaving and I want to quickly pipe the logs to OpInsight for analysis.

item.title: Converting Windows Server Core to Desktop for Debugging
item.description: Sometimes it’s necessary when debugging a machines issues to pop desktop support back on so you can RDP to the machine and quickly use tools that work properly rather than the half-arsed versions available via powershell where basic things like log viewing (get-events) requires you to faff and filter the log request down just so you can pipe it into another chunk of powershell to get the full log row as god forbid they learn how line wrap works or let you scroll like any linux shell / journalctl would.

item.title: Resetting Windows Server User Passwords
item.description: Quick and simple This is also useful for AWS when you have SSM setup but the servers created without a key; as it allows you to set the password via ssm then RDP normally. Remote to the machine / open powershell as admin Check current user Get-LocalUser Create new password you’ll use, as a secure-string $Password = Read-Host "Enter the new password" -AsSecureString Set the password of the user. (in this case admin) 1$UserAccount = Get-LocalUser -Name "administrator" 2$UserAccount | Set-LocalUser -Password $Password Done

item.title: Setting up rust on Windows
item.description: Note: there’s no actual solution here; just a list of attempts that fix one bit but then lead straight into the next breaking package. the openssl build fix worked fine. Setting up rust on Windows is surprisingly easy these days; right up till it isn’t. So first; prerequisites: Microsoft have a nice setup doc here https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/dev-environment/rust/setup Where I use paths that contain Visual Studio you should substitute that for build-tools paths as needed.
